Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Instrument: High Performance Reliable Network Access to Mauna Loa Observatory Science Instruments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project, "CC*DNI Instrument: High Performance Reliable Network Access to MLO Science Instruments", addresses the problem of network limitations at the Mauna Loa Observatory (MLO) located on the island of Hawaii in the Pacific ocean. The site is owned and operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Earth System Research Laboratory Global Monitoring Division and cooperatively used by the National Center for Atmospheric Research's High Altitude Observatory and the Institute for Astronomy, a research organization of the University of Hawaii (UH). A wide range of important science observation data is produced by the various instruments located at MLO. Among this data is a widely-used, 50+ year continuous record of atmospheric carbon dioxide levels at Mauna Loa. Less well known are data that measure ozone levels in the upper atmosphere, solar activity such as solar flares and coronal mass ejections, young variable stars and mid-size, potentially hazardous asteroids. This data is of national and global significance for policy and public safety and welfare decisions in areas related to measuring and predicting global warming, forecasting disruptions to communications and navigation caused by solar transient events and detecting and predicting Earth impacts of mid-sized asteroids.

Improvements to telescopes and instruments cause volumes of science data produced to increase exponentially over time. Commercial grade, licensed-spectrum wireless radio point-to-point network links are used to solve the critical "last mile" problem of connecting the science instruments located at MLO to the robust University of Hawaii (UH) network for transmission to researchers in Hawaii, the United States and across the globe. The MLO network supports a rapidly growing volume of data (>1.5TB/day) originating from instruments such as COSMO K- Coronagraph (KCor), Coronal Multi-channel Polarimeter (CoMP), Precision Solar Photometric Telescope (PSPT), Very Young Stellar Objects Survey (VYSOS), Asteroid Terrestrial-Impact Last Alert System (ATLAS) and COSMO Chromospheric Magnetometer (ChroMag). Expected science results made possible by these MLO network improvements include follow up observations of Near Earth Objects, supernovae, gamma ray bursts, and young variable stars; solar observations in real time for space weather forecasts and real-time atmospheric monitoring. The broader impact of the science enabled is to build and support global awareness of environmental and astronomy research, to enable collaborative research with global partners and support the dissemination of unique data sets of immense value to research communities, policy and decision makers and the lay public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to provide sufficient and reliable network bandwidth to science researchers at the Mauna Loa Observatory (MLO) site in Hawaii. The MLO site is owned by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association (NOAA) and hosts a range of university and national research in climate, astronomy and space weather science domains. The University of Hawaii, Manoa operates the regional research and engineering network (REN) in Hawaii and peers with regional RENs on the mainland and with Internet2. A secondary goal is to improve routing of research traffic by connecting the NOAA MLO site to the UH REN instead of using a commercial ISP. A third goal is to improve network reliability by establishing redundant links with automatic failover.


The level of stakeholder involvement in this project has been exemplary. At project inception, under the leadership of PI Dodds, representatives of the three primary stakeholders, University of Hawaii (UH), University Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR/UCAR) and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association (NOAA) worked as a team to provide shared governance of the project and to plan and implement the transition into sustainable operation. Stakeholders were added to a mailing list used to notify them of meetings and provide information about the network. During the transition to operations an additional ?MLONET-notify? mailing list was established for the purpose of disseminating time-sensitive information about scheduled maintenance and technical issues and their subsequent resolution. A shared Google Drive folder was used to organize project documentation. A Google Site was created to provide project information to stakeholders online.

Bi-monthly meetings are held using Google Hangouts and a phone bridge. Meetings have been well-attended and are essential for technical and financial governance of the network. They will continue indefinitely.

Major milestones accomplished for this project were the equipment requisition (03/22/16), equipment installation (07/21/16), network turn up (10/09/16), subnets routed (10/23/16), failover test (05/27/17), fully operational status (08/31/17) and cost sharing agreements (09/20/18).

The network has proven to be very stable with only one unplanned outage (caused by an exploding volcano) in two years of operation. Notably, the network was back in service as soon as power was restored while the commercial phone service took several days to be restored. The primary 2-channel radio links the MLO site with a relay site 25km away. A secondary, backup radio set links the MLO site to the same relay site. The relay site has two physically diverse WAN paths. The preferred path is via radio (OC3) to Univ. of Hawaii, Hilo campus where it goes to fiber. The backup path is via radio (OC3) to Univ. of Hawaii, Manoa campus where it goes to fiber after 5 radio repeater hops, 2 of which are over the ocean between islands. A tertiary backup radio set uses unlicensed 5GHz band to link the MLO site to the same relay site and to Univ. of Hawaii, Hilo campus by a second pair of unlicensed 5GHz band  radios.

 

The UH network has had significant improvements in peering and capacity over the course of this project due in large part to the NSF ACI -#1451058 "IRNC Backbone: SX TransPORT Pacific Islands Research and Education Network". Links to the mainland and Internet2 that were 10G at the start of this project are now 100G and additional 100G links have been added.

The bandwidth available for science research at MLO was increased from 135Mbps to 310Mbps. However, the network is normally operated in a triple redundant configuration at 155Mbps rather than at the full capacity of 310Mbps. This is possible because the major bandwidth consumption overlaps between solar (UCAR) in the daytime and nighttime astronomy (IfA). When ChroMag comes online we will operate at the full 310Mbps capacity.

The supporting role of network infrastructure makes science research at remote sites possible. Science impacted by this project includes HAO monitoring the Sun for coronal mass ejections, ATLAS surveying the night sky for Earth-impacting asteroids and NOAA's famous "Keeling Curve" CO2 data that is evidence of global warming. Because the network supports the scientific research conducted at the MLO site, this project has impact on space weather prediction (potentially devastating magnetic disruptions on Earth caused by solar flares and coronal mass ejections), the discovery and advance warning of potentially hazardous Earth-impacting asteroids and measuring the rate of global warming.
